issue.title: [PROPOSAL] - dual speed release tempo

labels.name: To-Be-triageD
labels.description: New issues and proposals to be validated/assigned by project leads

issue.body:
_Desired outcome_

It is common for consumer and even enterprise software to have a choice of release tempos: a slower moving but "stable" and perhaps a more frequent or "nightly" release schedule. 

_Current Gaps_

There aren't regular releases of all the components yet, so would be good to agree on what that might look like. Ideally they are released together (vs each project or component on its own, if possible).

_Implementation Suggestions (optional)_

Make main branch be the "nightly" - and a versioned strategy for stable releases (perhaps this can be flipped around? open to discussion)

comment.body:
+100 on basic automation first:

* CI
* Then CD (in our case, likely releases to repos)

For BOMs, a great discussion to have would be about what defines "the platform". Right now @nitro-neal's work in [`web5-components`](https://github.com/TBD54566975/web5-components-tests) brings things together, which effectively is a dependency set as a BOM. A cool place to get this to might be to externalize the what defines the "platform" so that the tests could run against different platform versions, validating them along the way.

Throwing thoughts here for a more comprehensive discussion; if there's an AI we want to propose from this here, I'm all ears!

It is common for consumer and even enterprise software to have a choice of release tempos: a slower moving but "stable" and perhaps a more frequent or "nightly" release schedule. 

_Current Gaps_

There aren't regular releases of all the components yet, so would be good to agree on what that might look like. Ideally they are released together (vs each project or component on its own, if possible).

comment.body:
You're considering this for Platform releases or the components themselves?

I'd love to see a Bill-of-Materials (BOM) type project which brings the Web5 Platform components together. That could identify versions as a set of dependencies and have structure:

* `main` - Latest development branch where components propose upgrades to the platform and are checked by system tests
* `stable` - Lastest stable branch from which releases are cut
* `development` - Branch for next-gen ideas, or perhaps even branch-per-exploratory feature?

Does a BOM-type project start to address what you're raising here?

issue.title: [PROPOSAL] - Organize Discord to Better Engage Community

labels.name: To-Be-triageD
labels.description: New issues and proposals to be validated/assigned by project leads

issue.body:
**Desired outcome**
Discord is an opportunity for our community to connect and discuss informally. At time of this writing, it has ~6k members. We desire a clear path for folks to know how to get involved, where discussions should take place, and a low barrier to getting them to productive ends. 

**Current Gaps**
The existing Discord setup has grown to many channels and lacks clear guidance about where to go and what types of wins we can give them. There's a clear opportunity here to:

* Slim the channels around discussions and actions that may be helpful to consumers and contributors to our tech
* Ensure the descriptions set scope of the channel
* Inspect pinned messages for relevance
* Set content moderation standards and norms with TBD team and community (security issues handled separately)
* Set up schedule to routinely revisit Discord structure as noted in bullets above, and keep fresh

**Implementation Suggestions (optional)** 
To be proposed in Forum post and coordinated with TBD Open Source Engineering and the broader community

**Forum Discussion (optional)** 
TBD

**Discord Discussion (optional)** 
N/A

issue.title: [PROPOSAL] - Community Wiki

labels.name: To-Be-triageD
labels.description: New issues and proposals to be validated/assigned by project leads

issue.body:
**Desired outcome**
Comprehensive knowledge base for TBD projects and technolgies. Easily editable and grown in tandem with the community. Low barrier to docs contribution. More details around this in the linked forum proposal by `ag4536` below.

**Current Gaps**
Documentation right now lives on developer.tbd.website, which is maintained by TBD employees. Opening this up for forms of documentation that can be surfaced on the site likely has benefit for evergreen, more "official" docs like tutorials or learning modules. Still there's the opportunity to really lower the bar for contribution in a Wiki-like platform which lets folks from the community contribute in a lighter manner.

**Implementation Suggestions (optional)** 
Suggested: 
* Integrated with developer.tbd.website
* Consider: user account unification? Forums, Discord, Wiki, etc - too much? Is there a TBD account that can bring things together?
* Wiki platform analysis to be done as part of this work

**Forum Discussion (optional)** 
https://forums.tbd.website/t/how-about-a-web5-wiki/70

issue.title: [RFC] 1 WIP: Docs as Code
issue.body:
- RFC Name: Docs as Code - RFC ID: 1 - Start Date: 2022-08-22 - Contributors: @frankhinek, @ALRubinger, @saeedjabbar - Current Status: WIP # Summary Proposal to adopt a docs-as-code approach for developing a technical documentation system that helps orient newcomers, helps contributors acquire and apply knowledge, and helps create an inclusive community. # Context and Scope TBD's projects are developed in the public guided by an [open source philosophy](https://developer.tbd.website/open-source) with three foundational pillars: inclusivity, transparency, and clarity. This proposal is focused on making progress towards fulfilling these commitments: > - Anyone with the capacity to contribute: can. > - We are proactive in welcoming a diverse contributor base for our code, documentation, ... > - Decision-making is open by default, ... > - Projects need ... accessible, comprehensive documentation, a stellar Getting Started experience, and well-defined expectations. "Incomplete or confusing documentation" has [frequently been](https://opensourcesurvey.org/2017/) [cited](https://octoverse.github.com/creating-documentation/) as one of the top problems in open-source software development. Accurate, up-to-date, and well-organized documentation improves the first time contributor experience, creates a more inclusive environment, and can result in [significant productivity boosts](https://octoverse.github.com/creating-documentation/#docs-for-productivity-and-culture). Given the target audience for [developer.tbd.website](https://developer.tbd.website) and early stage of development for most TBD projects, it follows that the documentation should be optimized for the new contributor experience. Using a docs-as-code approach combines the power of developer tools with techniques to encourage community engagement and improve documentation quality. Treating docs-as-code means that document publishing follows a similar process to software development: - documentation is stored as plain text in a version control system - issues and pull requests track all documentation changes and decisions - additions and revisions are reviewed - approved documents are published without much human intervention By taking an open approach that is accessible and familiar to developers, TBD can establish a virtuous cycle by encouraging more community enhancements and feedback to improve the contributor experience, which in turn leads to more engagement. ## Goals - Anyone in the community can contribute enhancements, fixes, and ideas. - Documentation source files are stored in a publicly accessible repository. - Documentation and code/command examples in separate files. - Minimize the dependencies and onboarding steps for contributors. - The documentation repository is organized in a thoughtfully structured manner. - Changes to documents are reviewed and must be approved prior to publication. - All code and command examples are manually tested during review. - Once approved, document processing and artifact builds are automated. - Documentation is published to [developer.tbd.website](https://developer.tbd.website). ## Non-goals Several of these could reasonably be goals, but are explicitly chosen not to be goals in favor of releasing a minimum viable documentation system and receiving feedback from the community. - Definition of documentation templates - Automated code/command testing and linting - Multi-language support - Search - Support for JSX in Markdown documents (.mdx) # Proposal ## Document Format - Documentation text is stored as plain text files. - Markdown formatting is used to add style to plain text. - [CommonMark](https://commonmark.org) syntax specification for Markdown. - Code/command examples are stored separately from documentation text to minimize migration friction if/when automated testing is introduced. ## Documentation Processing - Target output format for inclusion in [developer.tbd.website](https://developer.tbd.website) is Markdown so that the Docusaurus-powered site can import post-processed Markdown files. - Use [remark](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark) to parse, transform, and serialize Markdown content. [Why remark?](#why-remark) - A new command-line utility, [tentatively tbdoc](https://github.com/frankhinek/prototype-tbdocs/tree/main/tbdoc), automatically transforms documentation source files into artifacts ready to be imported to [developer.tbd.website](https://developer.tbd.website). [Why wrap with Docker?](#why-docker) ## Repository Structure - Developed and maintained by the community on GitHub in a single @TBD54566975 repository. - Documentation is organized by topic to improve discovery, authoring, and maintenance (e.g., SSI Service, DWN, third-party integrations, etc.). - Each topic consists of: - Sub-directories for tutorials and how-to guides. - If appropriate, one or more Dockerfiles which are shared by topic documentation. Ideally, the Docker image definition maintained within the associated TBD project repo can be used to minimize maintenance. - A sub-directory is created for each tutorial or how-to guide and consists of: - Markdown files that contain the documentation text. - Images that support the content. - A `workflows` directory that contains an individual file for each command or code example. During the documentation build process, these files will be parsed and inserted inline with the documentation text. ![Repository Structure](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/134693/189328225-845e940f-b34c-493a-8d68-54772ebaf478.svg) "[Overview of the Galaxy Training Material](https://training.galaxyproject.org/training-material/topics/contributing/slides/introduction.html)" by [Bérénice Batut](https://training.galaxyproject.org/training-material/hall-of-fame/bebatut/), used under [CC BY](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/) / Redrawn and colorized ## Documentation Flows Document publishing follows a similar process to software development: ```mermaid %%{init: { 'logLevel': 'debug', 'theme': 'base', 'gitGraph': {'showBranches': true, 'showCommitLabel':false,'mainBranchName': 'main'}} }%% gitGraph commit commit tag:"Create Branch" branch new-topic commit commit commit type: HIGHLIGHT tag:"Open PR" commit commit commit tag:"Review & Improvement" commit checkout main merge new-topic tag:"PR Merged" commit commit ``` ### Authoring New Content 1. Contributor forks the TBD community docs repo on GitHub and creates a new branch. 3. Contributor creates the directory structure scaffolding for a new tutorial. 4. Contributor authors the document, including any command/code and/or images. 5. Contributor opens a pull request (PR) in the TBD community docs repo. 6. TBD and community members review, manually test command/code examples, and provide feedback. 7. If approved, the PR is merged to the TBD community docs repo. 8. GitHub Actions automatically process the contributed docs and open a PR on the TBD Developer Site. ### Suggesting a Fix or Improvement 1. Contributor opens an Issue or PR in the TBD GitHub repo. 2. TBD and community members review and provide feedback. 4. If approved, a PR is created (if starting as an Issue) and approved/merged. 5. Automated workflow publishes the revised content. # Definition of success - Community contributors author, submit, and have their content published to [developer.tbd.website](developer.tbd.website). - Positive feedback is received from the community. - The docs-as-code approach and design proposal can be adapted to automate publishing to [developer.tbd.website](developer.tbd.website). - This design can be enhanced and extended over time as a function of being modular and flexible. # Open Questions 1. After a community contribution is approved and merged into the community docs repo, a GitHub Action will automatically create a PR in the TBD Developer Site. When this action is creating the PR, should it create a new branch and PR for each approved push to the community docs repo? Or should any additional pushes to the community docs repo main branch be added to the open TBD Developer Site PR until it is approved or closed? # Appendix ## Alternatives Considered - [MarkdownPP](https://github.com/jreese/markdown-pp) - [Pandoc 3](https://pandoc.org) - [Antora](https://antora.org) - [Gitdown](https://github.com/gajus/gitdown) - [Markdoc](https://markdoc.io) - [Postman API Platform](https://www.postman.com/api-platform/) - [Gitbook](https://www.gitbook.com) - [Mkdocs](https://www.mkdocs.org) - [ReadMe](https://readme.com) ## Design Decision Rationale

Why Remark?

- Can be easily extended with linting, grammar, and language use plugins to drive up the quality of the documentation and make it more accessible to groups that are underrepresented in open source software development. - Markdown parsing engine used by Docusaurus, MDX, Node.js docs, GitHub Docs, and [many other projects](http://unifiedjs.com/community/case/). - The [most downloaded](https://www.npmtrends.com/remark-parse-vs-marked-vs-micromark-vs-markdown-it) Markdown parser. - 100% [compliant](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark#syntax) to CommonMark and 100% to GitHub Flavored Markdown (GFM) with a plugin. - Hundreds of available [plugins](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark#plugins) to support a broad variety of use cases and workflows.

Why encapsulate utility tools/scripts with Docker?

- One of the high priority goals for this proposal is that _Anyone in the community can contribute..._, and to that end, a secondary objective is to _Minimize the dependencies and onboarding steps for contributors_. By encapsulating utility tools/scripts using a Docker container, the only dependency a contributor must satisfy is a local installation of a Docker engine. - For documentation contributors whose strengths are in technical writing or who aren't polyglot programmers, the major benefit to this approach is eliminating onboarding steps such as installing runtime environments (e.g., Node.js, JVM, etc.), modifying the `PATH` environment variable, or managing multiple runtime environment versions needed to satisfy different project requirements (e.g., Node 10 vs. 16). - Docker containers run applications in a consistent, isolated environment which helps to ensure that more contributors are successful when using the tools and less community time is spent troubleshooting. ## Decision Log 1. Docusaurus is used for [developer.tbd.website](https://developer.tbd.website), which supports [MDX](https://mdxjs.com/docs/what-is-mdx/). Should we support including JSX in markdown content for community-contributed docs? **DECISION**: MDX/JSX will not be supported in the initial release. **Additional Context**: There may be complications related to how Docusaurus handles MDX and incorporates external Markdown. Long term we may want to offer docs authors greater flexibility in styling by exposing JSX directly. In service of MVP, we will limit the scope to exclude support for community contributors authoring MDX and release a system which lets us author in Markdown, embed code and images and publish content on the TBD Developer Site. 2. When new documentation is approved and PRs merged, GitHub Actions can be triggered to build the doc artifacts and potentially trigger publishing to [developer.tbd.website](https://develop.tbd.website). Should this workflow run in the main Docusaurus site repo or the community-contributed docs repo? What additional steps can we take to automate the publication process and minimize human intervention? **DECISION**: The community-contributed docs repo will use GitHub Actions to build the output Markdown and trigger a Pull Request on the TBD Developer Site repo. **Additional Context**: The community-contributed docs repo can run builds to compose the output Markdown, and then we trigger a PR into the Developer Site repo to update/add the newly-generated page? This would let us always revert the Developer Site if we needed, and makes clear when a new piece of content is to be published, while letting the docs repo handle its own build to generate the markdown.

comment.body:
This is amazing. Thanks for the patience while I've found the time to grok the comprehensive docs and instructions you've laid out here. All ran great here and I totally see where you're going with this workflow. Eager to get it into the repo and hook things together, and I've granted you admin access here.

I've written up some more details on the forum thread. 

To your open questions:

>Docusaurus is used for [developer.tbd.website](https://developer.tbd.website/), which supports [MDX](https://mdxjs.com/docs/what-is-mdx/). Should we support including JSX in markdown content for community-contributed docs?
> This one may get murky as I believe it's tied into how Docusaurus handles MDX and pulling in external Markdown. Long term we may want to offer docs authors greater flexibility in styling by exposing JSX directly. In service of MVP I'd be thrilled to start by releasing a system which lets us author in Markdown, embed code and images as you've shown, and get things published on the Developer Site. WDYT?

Exactly as you suggest. Let's get some Markdown where we can embed code and images and iterate from there. That alone is a huge win for bootstrapping contribution and getting it published.

> When new documentation is approved and PRs merged, GitHub Actions can be triggered to build the doc artifacts and potentially trigger publishing to [developer.tbd.website](https://develop.tbd.website/). Should this workflow run in the main Docusaurus site repo or the community-contributed docs repo? What additional steps can we take to automate the publication process and minimize human intervention?
> Hot takes: chained builds? The community-contributed docs repo can run builds to compose the output Markdown, and then we trigger a PR into the Developer Site repo to update/add the newly-generated page? This would let us always revert the Developer Site if we needed, and makes clear when a new piece of content is to be published, while letting the docs repo handle its own build to generate the markdown.

Love the chained builds approach and it's given me success before. Because: then we've cleanly decoupled the docs contribution piece into its own workflow, and the publishing step will show us in each commit exactly what's to be pushed live on the dev site. Also makes for a super clean audit trail in the case we need to roll back changes on the Dev Site. I'm hoping this is a really easy contribution path for people by letting them focus only on the writing and docs generation, knowing the grander details of publishing will just (waves magic wand) be handled for them through automation.

@saeedjabbar had an open question too:

> Q: Does the current developer.tbd.website Docusaurus instance already have i18n configured, and if so, can you share a few details that can guide how to structure community contributed docs?

Docusaurus has i18n support but we're not taking advantage of it yet, and I'm thinking that once we get this plugged in, i18n is an awesome thing to enable and let the community run with for translations. I was once astounded at how eager folks were to translate the [Arquillian Quides](https://arquillian.org/guides/) into so many languages.

fix: switch back to root user for tbdoc Docker image

Signed-off-by: Frank Hinek <frankhinek@users.noreply.github.com>

Revert the tbdoc executable Docker container to use the /app dir

Permissions errors are encountered when running the tbdoc utility
as a non-root user on GitHub Action runners. To enable this
utility to process Markdown files for both local development
and during GitHub Actions workflows, commands must be run under
the root user.  To avoid the misperception that Node.js packages
under /home/node/app are run by a non-root user, the container
will be reverted to storing packages under /app.

issue.body:
_Desired outcome_

It is common for consumer and even enterprise software to have a choice of release tempos: a slower moving but "stable" and perhaps a more frequent or "nightly" release schedule. 

_Current Gaps_

There aren't regular releases of all the components yet, so would be good to agree on what that might look like. Ideally they are released together (vs each project or component on its own, if possible).

_Implementation Suggestions (optional)_

Make main branch be the "nightly" - and a versioned strategy for stable releases (perhaps this can be flipped around? open to discussion)

comment.body:
+100 on basic automation first:

* CI
* Then CD (in our case, likely releases to repos)

For BOMs, a great discussion to have would be about what defines "the platform". Right now @nitro-neal's work in [`web5-components`](https://github.com/TBD54566975/web5-components-tests) brings things together, which effectively is a dependency set as a BOM. A cool place to get this to might be to externalize the what defines the "platform" so that the tests could run against different platform versions, validating them along the way.

Throwing thoughts here for a more comprehensive discussion; if there's an AI we want to propose from this here, I'm all ears!

comment.body:
You're considering this for Platform releases or the components themselves?

I'd love to see a Bill-of-Materials (BOM) type project which brings the Web5 Platform components together. That could identify versions as a set of dependencies and have structure:

* `main` - Latest development branch where components propose upgrades to the platform and are checked by system tests
* `stable` - Lastest stable branch from which releases are cut
* `development` - Branch for next-gen ideas, or perhaps even branch-per-exploratory feature?

Does a BOM-type project start to address what you're raising here?

issue.title: [PROPOSAL] - Organize Discord to Better Engage Community

labels.name: To-Be-triageD
labels.description: New issues and proposals to be validated/assigned by project leads

issue.body:
**Desired outcome**
Discord is an opportunity for our community to connect and discuss informally. At time of this writing, it has ~6k members. We desire a clear path for folks to know how to get involved, where discussions should take place, and a low barrier to getting them to productive ends. 

**Current Gaps**
The existing Discord setup has grown to many channels and lacks clear guidance about where to go and what types of wins we can give them. There's a clear opportunity here to:

* Slim the channels around discussions and actions that may be helpful to consumers and contributors to our tech
* Ensure the descriptions set scope of the channel
* Inspect pinned messages for relevance
* Set content moderation standards and norms with TBD team and community (security issues handled separately)
* Set up schedule to routinely revisit Discord structure as noted in bullets above, and keep fresh

**Implementation Suggestions (optional)** 
To be proposed in Forum post and coordinated with TBD Open Source Engineering and the broader community

TBD

issue.title: [PROPOSAL] - Community Wiki

labels.name: To-Be-triageD
labels.description: New issues and proposals to be validated/assigned by project leads

issue.body:
**Desired outcome**
Comprehensive knowledge base for TBD projects and technolgies. Easily editable and grown in tandem with the community. Low barrier to docs contribution. More details around this in the linked forum proposal by `ag4536` below.

**Current Gaps**
Documentation right now lives on developer.tbd.website, which is maintained by TBD employees. Opening this up for forms of documentation that can be surfaced on the site likely has benefit for evergreen, more "official" docs like tutorials or learning modules. Still there's the opportunity to really lower the bar for contribution in a Wiki-like platform which lets folks from the community contribute in a lighter manner.

**Implementation Suggestions (optional)** 
Suggested: 
* Integrated with developer.tbd.website
* Consider: user account unification? Forums, Discord, Wiki, etc - too much? Is there a TBD account that can bring things together?
* Wiki platform analysis to be done as part of this work

**Forum Discussion (optional)** 
https://forums.tbd.website/t/how-about-a-web5-wiki/70

issue.title: [RFC] 1 WIP: Docs as Code
issue.body:
- RFC Name: Docs as Code - RFC ID: 1 - Start Date: 2022-08-22 - Contributors: @frankhinek, @ALRubinger, @saeedjabbar - Current Status: WIP # Summary Proposal to adopt a docs-as-code approach for developing a technical documentation system that helps orient newcomers, helps contributors acquire and apply knowledge, and helps create an inclusive community. # Context and Scope TBD's projects are developed in the public guided by an [open source philosophy](https://developer.tbd.website/open-source) with three foundational pillars: inclusivity, transparency, and clarity. This proposal is focused on making progress towards fulfilling these commitments: > - Anyone with the capacity to contribute: can. > - We are proactive in welcoming a diverse contributor base for our code, documentation, ... > - Decision-making is open by default, ... > - Projects need ... accessible, comprehensive documentation, a stellar Getting Started experience, and well-defined expectations. "Incomplete or confusing documentation" has [frequently been](https://opensourcesurvey.org/2017/) [cited](https://octoverse.github.com/creating-documentation/) as one of the top problems in open-source software development. Accurate, up-to-date, and well-organized documentation improves the first time contributor experience, creates a more inclusive environment, and can result in [significant productivity boosts](https://octoverse.github.com/creating-documentation/#docs-for-productivity-and-culture). Given the target audience for [developer.tbd.website](https://developer.tbd.website) and early stage of development for most TBD projects, it follows that the documentation should be optimized for the new contributor experience. Using a docs-as-code approach combines the power of developer tools with techniques to encourage community engagement and improve documentation quality. Treating docs-as-code means that document publishing follows a similar process to software development: - documentation is stored as plain text in a version control system - issues and pull requests track all documentation changes and decisions - additions and revisions are reviewed - approved documents are published without much human intervention By taking an open approach that is accessible and familiar to developers, TBD can establish a virtuous cycle by encouraging more community enhancements and feedback to improve the contributor experience, which in turn leads to more engagement. ## Goals - Anyone in the community can contribute enhancements, fixes, and ideas. - Documentation source files are stored in a publicly accessible repository. - Documentation and code/command examples in separate files. - Minimize the dependencies and onboarding steps for contributors. - The documentation repository is organized in a thoughtfully structured manner. - Changes to documents are reviewed and must be approved prior to publication. - All code and command examples are manually tested during review. - Once approved, document processing and artifact builds are automated. - Documentation is published to [developer.tbd.website](https://developer.tbd.website). ## Non-goals Several of these could reasonably be goals, but are explicitly chosen not to be goals in favor of releasing a minimum viable documentation system and receiving feedback from the community. - Definition of documentation templates - Automated code/command testing and linting - Multi-language support - Search - Support for JSX in Markdown documents (.mdx) # Proposal ## Document Format - Documentation text is stored as plain text files. - Markdown formatting is used to add style to plain text. - [CommonMark](https://commonmark.org) syntax specification for Markdown. - Code/command examples are stored separately from documentation text to minimize migration friction if/when automated testing is introduced. ## Documentation Processing - Target output format for inclusion in [developer.tbd.website](https://developer.tbd.website) is Markdown so that the Docusaurus-powered site can import post-processed Markdown files. - Use [remark](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark) to parse, transform, and serialize Markdown content. [Why remark?](#why-remark) - A new command-line utility, [tentatively tbdoc](https://github.com/frankhinek/prototype-tbdocs/tree/main/tbdoc), automatically transforms documentation source files into artifacts ready to be imported to [developer.tbd.website](https://developer.tbd.website). [Why wrap with Docker?](#why-docker) ## Repository Structure - Developed and maintained by the community on GitHub in a single @TBD54566975 repository. - Documentation is organized by topic to improve discovery, authoring, and maintenance (e.g., SSI Service, DWN, third-party integrations, etc.). - Each topic consists of: - Sub-directories for tutorials and how-to guides. - If appropriate, one or more Dockerfiles which are shared by topic documentation. Ideally, the Docker image definition maintained within the associated TBD project repo can be used to minimize maintenance. - A sub-directory is created for each tutorial or how-to guide and consists of: - Markdown files that contain the documentation text. - Images that support the content. - A `workflows` directory that contains an individual file for each command or code example. During the documentation build process, these files will be parsed and inserted inline with the documentation text. ![Repository Structure](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/134693/189328225-845e940f-b34c-493a-8d68-54772ebaf478.svg) "[Overview of the Galaxy Training Material](https://training.galaxyproject.org/training-material/topics/contributing/slides/introduction.html)" by [Bérénice Batut](https://training.galaxyproject.org/training-material/hall-of-fame/bebatut/), used under [CC BY](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/) / Redrawn and colorized ## Documentation Flows Document publishing follows a similar process to software development: ```mermaid %%{init: { 'logLevel': 'debug', 'theme': 'base', 'gitGraph': {'showBranches': true, 'showCommitLabel':false,'mainBranchName': 'main'}} }%% gitGraph commit commit tag:"Create Branch" branch new-topic commit commit commit type: HIGHLIGHT tag:"Open PR" commit commit commit tag:"Review & Improvement" commit checkout main merge new-topic tag:"PR Merged" commit commit ``` ### Authoring New Content 1. Contributor forks the TBD community docs repo on GitHub and creates a new branch. 3. Contributor creates the directory structure scaffolding for a new tutorial. 4. Contributor authors the document, including any command/code and/or images. 5. Contributor opens a pull request (PR) in the TBD community docs repo. 6. TBD and community members review, manually test command/code examples, and provide feedback. 7. If approved, the PR is merged to the TBD community docs repo. 8. GitHub Actions automatically process the contributed docs and open a PR on the TBD Developer Site. ### Suggesting a Fix or Improvement 1. Contributor opens an Issue or PR in the TBD GitHub repo. 2. TBD and community members review and provide feedback. 4. If approved, a PR is created (if starting as an Issue) and approved/merged. 5. Automated workflow publishes the revised content. # Definition of success - Community contributors author, submit, and have their content published to [developer.tbd.website](developer.tbd.website). - Positive feedback is received from the community. - The docs-as-code approach and design proposal can be adapted to automate publishing to [developer.tbd.website](developer.tbd.website). - This design can be enhanced and extended over time as a function of being modular and flexible. # Open Questions 1. After a community contribution is approved and merged into the community docs repo, a GitHub Action will automatically create a PR in the TBD Developer Site. When this action is creating the PR, should it create a new branch and PR for each approved push to the community docs repo? Or should any additional pushes to the community docs repo main branch be added to the open TBD Developer Site PR until it is approved or closed? # Appendix ## Alternatives Considered - [MarkdownPP](https://github.com/jreese/markdown-pp) - [Pandoc 3](https://pandoc.org) - [Antora](https://antora.org) - [Gitdown](https://github.com/gajus/gitdown) - [Markdoc](https://markdoc.io) - [Postman API Platform](https://www.postman.com/api-platform/) - [Gitbook](https://www.gitbook.com) - [Mkdocs](https://www.mkdocs.org) - [ReadMe](https://readme.com) ## Design Decision Rationale

Why Remark?

- Can be easily extended with linting, grammar, and language use plugins to drive up the quality of the documentation and make it more accessible to groups that are underrepresented in open source software development. - Markdown parsing engine used by Docusaurus, MDX, Node.js docs, GitHub Docs, and [many other projects](http://unifiedjs.com/community/case/). - The [most downloaded](https://www.npmtrends.com/remark-parse-vs-marked-vs-micromark-vs-markdown-it) Markdown parser. - 100% [compliant](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark#syntax) to CommonMark and 100% to GitHub Flavored Markdown (GFM) with a plugin. - Hundreds of available [plugins](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark#plugins) to support a broad variety of use cases and workflows.

Why encapsulate utility tools/scripts with Docker?

- One of the high priority goals for this proposal is that _Anyone in the community can contribute..._, and to that end, a secondary objective is to _Minimize the dependencies and onboarding steps for contributors_. By encapsulating utility tools/scripts using a Docker container, the only dependency a contributor must satisfy is a local installation of a Docker engine. - For documentation contributors whose strengths are in technical writing or who aren't polyglot programmers, the major benefit to this approach is eliminating onboarding steps such as installing runtime environments (e.g., Node.js, JVM, etc.), modifying the `PATH` environment variable, or managing multiple runtime environment versions needed to satisfy different project requirements (e.g., Node 10 vs. 16). - Docker containers run applications in a consistent, isolated environment which helps to ensure that more contributors are successful when using the tools and less community time is spent troubleshooting. ## Decision Log 1. Docusaurus is used for [developer.tbd.website](https://developer.tbd.website), which supports [MDX](https://mdxjs.com/docs/what-is-mdx/). Should we support including JSX in markdown content for community-contributed docs? **DECISION**: MDX/JSX will not be supported in the initial release. **Additional Context**: There may be complications related to how Docusaurus handles MDX and incorporates external Markdown. Long term we may want to offer docs authors greater flexibility in styling by exposing JSX directly. In service of MVP, we will limit the scope to exclude support for community contributors authoring MDX and release a system which lets us author in Markdown, embed code and images and publish content on the TBD Developer Site. 2. When new documentation is approved and PRs merged, GitHub Actions can be triggered to build the doc artifacts and potentially trigger publishing to [developer.tbd.website](https://develop.tbd.website). Should this workflow run in the main Docusaurus site repo or the community-contributed docs repo? What additional steps can we take to automate the publication process and minimize human intervention? **DECISION**: The community-contributed docs repo will use GitHub Actions to build the output Markdown and trigger a Pull Request on the TBD Developer Site repo. **Additional Context**: The community-contributed docs repo can run builds to compose the output Markdown, and then we trigger a PR into the Developer Site repo to update/add the newly-generated page? This would let us always revert the Developer Site if we needed, and makes clear when a new piece of content is to be published, while letting the docs repo handle its own build to generate the markdown.

comment.body:
This is amazing. Thanks for the patience while I've found the time to grok the comprehensive docs and instructions you've laid out here. All ran great here and I totally see where you're going with this workflow. Eager to get it into the repo and hook things together, and I've granted you admin access here.

I've written up some more details on the forum thread. 

To your open questions:

>Docusaurus is used for [developer.tbd.website](https://developer.tbd.website/), which supports [MDX](https://mdxjs.com/docs/what-is-mdx/). Should we support including JSX in markdown content for community-contributed docs?
> This one may get murky as I believe it's tied into how Docusaurus handles MDX and pulling in external Markdown. Long term we may want to offer docs authors greater flexibility in styling by exposing JSX directly. In service of MVP I'd be thrilled to start by releasing a system which lets us author in Markdown, embed code and images as you've shown, and get things published on the Developer Site. WDYT?

Exactly as you suggest. Let's get some Markdown where we can embed code and images and iterate from there. That alone is a huge win for bootstrapping contribution and getting it published.

> When new documentation is approved and PRs merged, GitHub Actions can be triggered to build the doc artifacts and potentially trigger publishing to [developer.tbd.website](https://develop.tbd.website/). Should this workflow run in the main Docusaurus site repo or the community-contributed docs repo? What additional steps can we take to automate the publication process and minimize human intervention?
> Hot takes: chained builds? The community-contributed docs repo can run builds to compose the output Markdown, and then we trigger a PR into the Developer Site repo to update/add the newly-generated page? This would let us always revert the Developer Site if we needed, and makes clear when a new piece of content is to be published, while letting the docs repo handle its own build to generate the markdown.

Love the chained builds approach and it's given me success before. Because: then we've cleanly decoupled the docs contribution piece into its own workflow, and the publishing step will show us in each commit exactly what's to be pushed live on the dev site. Also makes for a super clean audit trail in the case we need to roll back changes on the Dev Site. I'm hoping this is a really easy contribution path for people by letting them focus only on the writing and docs generation, knowing the grander details of publishing will just (waves magic wand) be handled for them through automation.

@saeedjabbar had an open question too:

> Q: Does the current developer.tbd.website Docusaurus instance already have i18n configured, and if so, can you share a few details that can guide how to structure community contributed docs?

Docusaurus has i18n support but we're not taking advantage of it yet, and I'm thinking that once we get this plugged in, i18n is an awesome thing to enable and let the community run with for translations. I was once astounded at how eager folks were to translate the [Arquillian Quides](https://arquillian.org/guides/) into so many languages.

issue.body:
_Desired outcome_

It is common for consumer and even enterprise software to have a choice of release tempos: a slower moving but "stable" and perhaps a more frequent or "nightly" release schedule. 

_Current Gaps_

There aren't regular releases of all the components yet, so would be good to agree on what that might look like. Ideally they are released together (vs each project or component on its own, if possible).

_Implementation Suggestions (optional)_

Make main branch be the "nightly" - and a versioned strategy for stable releases (perhaps this can be flipped around? open to discussion)

comment.body:
+100 on basic automation first:

* CI
* Then CD (in our case, likely releases to repos)

For BOMs, a great discussion to have would be about what defines "the platform". Right now @nitro-neal's work in [`web5-components`](https://github.com/TBD54566975/web5-components-tests) brings things together, which effectively is a dependency set as a BOM. A cool place to get this to might be to externalize the what defines the "platform" so that the tests could run against different platform versions, validating them along the way.

Throwing thoughts here for a more comprehensive discussion; if there's an AI we want to propose from this here, I'm all ears!

comment.body:
You're considering this for Platform releases or the components themselves?

I'd love to see a Bill-of-Materials (BOM) type project which brings the Web5 Platform components together. That could identify versions as a set of dependencies and have structure:

* `main` - Latest development branch where components propose upgrades to the platform and are checked by system tests
* `stable` - Lastest stable branch from which releases are cut
* `development` - Branch for next-gen ideas, or perhaps even branch-per-exploratory feature?

Does a BOM-type project start to address what you're raising here?

labels.name: To-Be-triageD
labels.description: New issues and proposals to be validated/assigned by project leads

issue.body:
**Desired outcome**
Discord is an opportunity for our community to connect and discuss informally. At time of this writing, it has ~6k members. We desire a clear path for folks to know how to get involved, where discussions should take place, and a low barrier to getting them to productive ends. 

**Current Gaps**
The existing Discord setup has grown to many channels and lacks clear guidance about where to go and what types of wins we can give them. There's a clear opportunity here to:

* Slim the channels around discussions and actions that may be helpful to consumers and contributors to our tech
* Ensure the descriptions set scope of the channel
* Inspect pinned messages for relevance
* Set content moderation standards and norms with TBD team and community (security issues handled separately)
* Set up schedule to routinely revisit Discord structure as noted in bullets above, and keep fresh

**Implementation Suggestions (optional)** 
To be proposed in Forum post and coordinated with TBD Open Source Engineering and the broader community

TBD

issue.title: [PROPOSAL] - Community Wiki

labels.name: To-Be-triageD
labels.description: New issues and proposals to be validated/assigned by project leads

issue.body:
**Desired outcome**
Comprehensive knowledge base for TBD projects and technolgies. Easily editable and grown in tandem with the community. Low barrier to docs contribution. More details around this in the linked forum proposal by `ag4536` below.

**Current Gaps**
Documentation right now lives on developer.tbd.website, which is maintained by TBD employees. Opening this up for forms of documentation that can be surfaced on the site likely has benefit for evergreen, more "official" docs like tutorials or learning modules. Still there's the opportunity to really lower the bar for contribution in a Wiki-like platform which lets folks from the community contribute in a lighter manner.

**Implementation Suggestions (optional)** 
Suggested: 
* Integrated with developer.tbd.website
* Consider: user account unification? Forums, Discord, Wiki, etc - too much? Is there a TBD account that can bring things together?
* Wiki platform analysis to be done as part of this work

**Forum Discussion (optional)** 
https://forums.tbd.website/t/how-about-a-web5-wiki/70

issue.title: [RFC] 1 WIP: Docs as Code
issue.body:
- RFC Name: Docs as Code - RFC ID: 1 - Start Date: 2022-08-22 - Contributors: @frankhinek, @ALRubinger, @saeedjabbar - Current Status: WIP # Summary Proposal to adopt a docs-as-code approach for developing a technical documentation system that helps orient newcomers, helps contributors acquire and apply knowledge, and helps create an inclusive community. # Context and Scope TBD's projects are developed in the public guided by an [open source philosophy](https://developer.tbd.website/open-source) with three foundational pillars: inclusivity, transparency, and clarity. This proposal is focused on making progress towards fulfilling these commitments: > - Anyone with the capacity to contribute: can. > - We are proactive in welcoming a diverse contributor base for our code, documentation, ... > - Decision-making is open by default, ... > - Projects need ... accessible, comprehensive documentation, a stellar Getting Started experience, and well-defined expectations. "Incomplete or confusing documentation" has [frequently been](https://opensourcesurvey.org/2017/) [cited](https://octoverse.github.com/creating-documentation/) as one of the top problems in open-source software development. Accurate, up-to-date, and well-organized documentation improves the first time contributor experience, creates a more inclusive environment, and can result in [significant productivity boosts](https://octoverse.github.com/creating-documentation/#docs-for-productivity-and-culture). Given the target audience for [developer.tbd.website](https://developer.tbd.website) and early stage of development for most TBD projects, it follows that the documentation should be optimized for the new contributor experience. Using a docs-as-code approach combines the power of developer tools with techniques to encourage community engagement and improve documentation quality. Treating docs-as-code means that document publishing follows a similar process to software development: - documentation is stored as plain text in a version control system - issues and pull requests track all documentation changes and decisions - additions and revisions are reviewed - approved documents are published without much human intervention By taking an open approach that is accessible and familiar to developers, TBD can establish a virtuous cycle by encouraging more community enhancements and feedback to improve the contributor experience, which in turn leads to more engagement. ## Goals - Anyone in the community can contribute enhancements, fixes, and ideas. - Documentation source files are stored in a publicly accessible repository. - Documentation and code/command examples in separate files. - Minimize the dependencies and onboarding steps for contributors. - The documentation repository is organized in a thoughtfully structured manner. - Changes to documents are reviewed and must be approved prior to publication. - All code and command examples are manually tested during review. - Once approved, document processing and artifact builds are automated. - Documentation is published to [developer.tbd.website](https://developer.tbd.website). ## Non-goals Several of these could reasonably be goals, but are explicitly chosen not to be goals in favor of releasing a minimum viable documentation system and receiving feedback from the community. - Definition of documentation templates - Automated code/command testing and linting - Multi-language support - Search - Support for JSX in Markdown documents (.mdx) # Proposal ## Document Format - Documentation text is stored as plain text files. - Markdown formatting is used to add style to plain text. - [CommonMark](https://commonmark.org) syntax specification for Markdown. - Code/command examples are stored separately from documentation text to minimize migration friction if/when automated testing is introduced. ## Documentation Processing - Target output format for inclusion in [developer.tbd.website](https://developer.tbd.website) is Markdown so that the Docusaurus-powered site can import post-processed Markdown files. - Use [remark](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark) to parse, transform, and serialize Markdown content. [Why remark?](#why-remark) - A new command-line utility, [tentatively tbdoc](https://github.com/frankhinek/prototype-tbdocs/tree/main/tbdoc), automatically transforms documentation source files into artifacts ready to be imported to [developer.tbd.website](https://developer.tbd.website). [Why wrap with Docker?](#why-docker) ## Repository Structure - Developed and maintained by the community on GitHub in a single @TBD54566975 repository. - Documentation is organized by topic to improve discovery, authoring, and maintenance (e.g., SSI Service, DWN, third-party integrations, etc.). - Each topic consists of: - Sub-directories for tutorials and how-to guides. - If appropriate, one or more Dockerfiles which are shared by topic documentation. Ideally, the Docker image definition maintained within the associated TBD project repo can be used to minimize maintenance. - A sub-directory is created for each tutorial or how-to guide and consists of: - Markdown files that contain the documentation text. - Images that support the content. - A `workflows` directory that contains an individual file for each command or code example. During the documentation build process, these files will be parsed and inserted inline with the documentation text. ![Repository Structure](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/134693/189328225-845e940f-b34c-493a-8d68-54772ebaf478.svg) "[Overview of the Galaxy Training Material](https://training.galaxyproject.org/training-material/topics/contributing/slides/introduction.html)" by [Bérénice Batut](https://training.galaxyproject.org/training-material/hall-of-fame/bebatut/), used under [CC BY](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/) / Redrawn and colorized ## Documentation Flows Document publishing follows a similar process to software development: ```mermaid %%{init: { 'logLevel': 'debug', 'theme': 'base', 'gitGraph': {'showBranches': true, 'showCommitLabel':false,'mainBranchName': 'main'}} }%% gitGraph commit commit tag:"Create Branch" branch new-topic commit commit commit type: HIGHLIGHT tag:"Open PR" commit commit commit tag:"Review & Improvement" commit checkout main merge new-topic tag:"PR Merged" commit commit ``` ### Authoring New Content 1. Contributor forks the TBD community docs repo on GitHub and creates a new branch. 3. Contributor creates the directory structure scaffolding for a new tutorial. 4. Contributor authors the document, including any command/code and/or images. 5. Contributor opens a pull request (PR) in the TBD community docs repo. 6. TBD and community members review, manually test command/code examples, and provide feedback. 7. If approved, the PR is merged to the TBD community docs repo. 8. GitHub Actions automatically process the contributed docs and open a PR on the TBD Developer Site. ### Suggesting a Fix or Improvement 1. Contributor opens an Issue or PR in the TBD GitHub repo. 2. TBD and community members review and provide feedback. 4. If approved, a PR is created (if starting as an Issue) and approved/merged. 5. Automated workflow publishes the revised content. # Definition of success - Community contributors author, submit, and have their content published to [developer.tbd.website](developer.tbd.website). - Positive feedback is received from the community. - The docs-as-code approach and design proposal can be adapted to automate publishing to [developer.tbd.website](developer.tbd.website). - This design can be enhanced and extended over time as a function of being modular and flexible. # Open Questions 1. After a community contribution is approved and merged into the community docs repo, a GitHub Action will automatically create a PR in the TBD Developer Site. When this action is creating the PR, should it create a new branch and PR for each approved push to the community docs repo? Or should any additional pushes to the community docs repo main branch be added to the open TBD Developer Site PR until it is approved or closed? # Appendix ## Alternatives Considered - [MarkdownPP](https://github.com/jreese/markdown-pp) - [Pandoc 3](https://pandoc.org) - [Antora](https://antora.org) - [Gitdown](https://github.com/gajus/gitdown) - [Markdoc](https://markdoc.io) - [Postman API Platform](https://www.postman.com/api-platform/) - [Gitbook](https://www.gitbook.com) - [Mkdocs](https://www.mkdocs.org) - [ReadMe](https://readme.com) ## Design Decision Rationale

Why Remark?

- Can be easily extended with linting, grammar, and language use plugins to drive up the quality of the documentation and make it more accessible to groups that are underrepresented in open source software development. - Markdown parsing engine used by Docusaurus, MDX, Node.js docs, GitHub Docs, and [many other projects](http://unifiedjs.com/community/case/). - The [most downloaded](https://www.npmtrends.com/remark-parse-vs-marked-vs-micromark-vs-markdown-it) Markdown parser. - 100% [compliant](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark#syntax) to CommonMark and 100% to GitHub Flavored Markdown (GFM) with a plugin. - Hundreds of available [plugins](https://github.com/remarkjs/remark#plugins) to support a broad variety of use cases and workflows.

Why encapsulate utility tools/scripts with Docker?

- One of the high priority goals for this proposal is that _Anyone in the community can contribute..._, and to that end, a secondary objective is to _Minimize the dependencies and onboarding steps for contributors_. By encapsulating utility tools/scripts using a Docker container, the only dependency a contributor must satisfy is a local installation of a Docker engine. - For documentation contributors whose strengths are in technical writing or who aren't polyglot programmers, the major benefit to this approach is eliminating onboarding steps such as installing runtime environments (e.g., Node.js, JVM, etc.), modifying the `PATH` environment variable, or managing multiple runtime environment versions needed to satisfy different project requirements (e.g., Node 10 vs. 16). - Docker containers run applications in a consistent, isolated environment which helps to ensure that more contributors are successful when using the tools and less community time is spent troubleshooting. ## Decision Log 1. Docusaurus is used for [developer.tbd.website](https://developer.tbd.website), which supports [MDX](https://mdxjs.com/docs/what-is-mdx/). Should we support including JSX in markdown content for community-contributed docs? **DECISION**: MDX/JSX will not be supported in the initial release. **Additional Context**: There may be complications related to how Docusaurus handles MDX and incorporates external Markdown. Long term we may want to offer docs authors greater flexibility in styling by exposing JSX directly. In service of MVP, we will limit the scope to exclude support for community contributors authoring MDX and release a system which lets us author in Markdown, embed code and images and publish content on the TBD Developer Site. 2. When new documentation is approved and PRs merged, GitHub Actions can be triggered to build the doc artifacts and potentially trigger publishing to [developer.tbd.website](https://develop.tbd.website). Should this workflow run in the main Docusaurus site repo or the community-contributed docs repo? What additional steps can we take to automate the publication process and minimize human intervention? **DECISION**: The community-contributed docs repo will use GitHub Actions to build the output Markdown and trigger a Pull Request on the TBD Developer Site repo. **Additional Context**: The community-contributed docs repo can run builds to compose the output Markdown, and then we trigger a PR into the Developer Site repo to update/add the newly-generated page? This would let us always revert the Developer Site if we needed, and makes clear when a new piece of content is to be published, while letting the docs repo handle its own build to generate the markdown.

comment.body:
This is amazing. Thanks for the patience while I've found the time to grok the comprehensive docs and instructions you've laid out here. All ran great here and I totally see where you're going with this workflow. Eager to get it into the repo and hook things together, and I've granted you admin access here.

I've written up some more details on the forum thread. 

To your open questions:

>Docusaurus is used for [developer.tbd.website](https://developer.tbd.website/), which supports [MDX](https://mdxjs.com/docs/what-is-mdx/). Should we support including JSX in markdown content for community-contributed docs?
> This one may get murky as I believe it's tied into how Docusaurus handles MDX and pulling in external Markdown. Long term we may want to offer docs authors greater flexibility in styling by exposing JSX directly. In service of MVP I'd be thrilled to start by releasing a system which lets us author in Markdown, embed code and images as you've shown, and get things published on the Developer Site. WDYT?

Exactly as you suggest. Let's get some Markdown where we can embed code and images and iterate from there. That alone is a huge win for bootstrapping contribution and getting it published.

> When new documentation is approved and PRs merged, GitHub Actions can be triggered to build the doc artifacts and potentially trigger publishing to [developer.tbd.website](https://develop.tbd.website/). Should this workflow run in the main Docusaurus site repo or the community-contributed docs repo? What additional steps can we take to automate the publication process and minimize human intervention?
> Hot takes: chained builds? The community-contributed docs repo can run builds to compose the output Markdown, and then we trigger a PR into the Developer Site repo to update/add the newly-generated page? This would let us always revert the Developer Site if we needed, and makes clear when a new piece of content is to be published, while letting the docs repo handle its own build to generate the markdown.

Love the chained builds approach and it's given me success before. Because: then we've cleanly decoupled the docs contribution piece into its own workflow, and the publishing step will show us in each commit exactly what's to be pushed live on the dev site. Also makes for a super clean audit trail in the case we need to roll back changes on the Dev Site. I'm hoping this is a really easy contribution path for people by letting them focus only on the writing and docs generation, knowing the grander details of publishing will just (waves magic wand) be handled for them through automation.

@saeedjabbar had an open question too:

> Q: Does the current developer.tbd.website Docusaurus instance already have i18n configured, and if so, can you share a few details that can guide how to structure community contributed docs?

Docusaurus has i18n support but we're not taking advantage of it yet, and I'm thinking that once we get this plugged in, i18n is an awesome thing to enable and let the community run with for translations. I was once astounded at how eager folks were to translate the [Arquillian Quides](https://arquillian.org/guides/) into so many languages.

fix: switch back to root user for tbdoc Docker image

Signed-off-by: Frank Hinek <frankhinek@users.noreply.github.com>

Revert the tbdoc executable Docker container to use the /app dir

Permissions errors are encountered when running the tbdoc utility
as a non-root user on GitHub Action runners. To enable this
utility to process Markdown files for both local development
and during GitHub Actions workflows, commands must be run under
the root user.  To avoid the misperception that Node.js packages
under /home/node/app are run by a non-root user, the container
will be reverted to storing packages under /app.
